Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help defray the expenses of participants in two meetings of the "Northeast Analysis Network," the first of which will be held September 23-24, 2016, on the campus of the University of Rochester and the second of which will be held September 22-23, 2017, on the campus of Syracuse University.

The Northeast Analysis Network (NAN) will bring together once a year, for the coming two years, the analysis communities in the state of New York and neighboring states. The University of Rochester and Syracuse University will each host one conference (Rochester: NAN 2016; Syracuse: NAN 2017). Each conference will primarily feature talks by senior post-docs and finishing graduate students who are about to enter the job market. A magnet lectures by a leading researcher, the "Excelsior Lecture" (named after the motto of the state of New York) will serve as a catalyst for each conference. The Excelsior Lecturers are Jill Pipher (NAN 2017) and Svitlana Mayboroda (NAN 2017).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Northeast Analysis Network has achieved considerable success during its first three years of operation. The NAN conference at the University of Albany featured the Excelsior lecture by Alice Chang, a world-renown mathematician from Princeton University, as well as a number of shorter talks by strong regional speakers. The audience response was very enthusiastic and the level of interaction and research activity during the conference was particularly high. There is every reason to believe that this conference has significantly stimulated research activity in the Northeast for many years to come. 

The Northeast Analysis Conference in Albany revelaed that connections between analysis and related areas of mathematics such as geometry and combinatorics continue to thrive and increase in both depth and importance. We shall endeavor to focus on this emerging symbiosis in the future meetings. 

The conference featured a large number of strong women mathematicians, from beginning graduate students to well-known world-class mathematicians. The goals of inclusion and diversity are central to the Northeast Analysis Network modus operindus and we have achieved considerable success in this direction during the first three years of the program. We look forward to furthering this progress as the network gains strength and establishes new and intereting connections in the Northest region. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 08/21/2020
Modified by: Alex Iosevich
